message_1:
A factor analysis was conducted on a dataset with 10 variables, and it was found that there were 3 underlying factors that explained the data. The factor loadings for each variable on each factor are shown below:

| Variable | Factor 1 | Factor 2 | Factor 3 |
|----------|----------|----------|----------|
| 1        | 0.6      | 0.1      | 0.3      |
| 2        | 0.3      | 0.8      | 0.2      |
| 3        | 0.2      | 0.3      | 0.9      |
| 4        | 0.9      | 0.1      | 0.2      |
| 5        | 0.1      | 0.7      | 0.5      |
| 6        | 0.4      | 0.4      | 0.6      |
| 7        | 0.5      | 0.6      | 0.1      |
| 8        | 0.8      | 0.2      | 0.1      |
| 9        | 0.7      | 0.3      | 0.1      |
| 10       | 0.2      | 0.5      | 0.7      |

If a new observation has the following values for each variable: 

| Variable | Value |
|----------|-------|
| 1        | 2     |
| 2        | 3     |
| 3        | 5     |
| 4        | 1     |
| 5        | 4     |
| 6        | 2     |
| 7        | 5     |
| 8        | 1     |
| 9        | 5     |
| 10       | 3     |

What are the factor scores for this new observation on each underlying factor?
message_2:
To find the factor scores for the new observation on each underlying factor, we need to multiply the value of each variable by its corresponding factor loading and then sum the results for each factor. 

Factor 1 score = (2 * 0.6) + (3 * 0.3) + (5 * 0.2) + (1 * 0.9) + (4 * 0.1) + (2 * 0.4) + (5 * 0.5) + (1 * 0.8) + (5 * 0.7) + (3 * 0.2)
Factor 1 score = 1.2 + 0.9 + 1 + 0.9 + 0.4 + 0.8 + 2.5 + 0.8 + 3.5 + 0.6
Factor 1 score = 12.6

Factor 2 score = (2 * 0.1) + (3 * 0.8) + (5 * 0.3) + (1 * 0.1) + (4 * 0.7) + (2 * 0.4) + (5 * 0.6) + (1 * 0.2) + (5 * 0.3) + (3 * 0.5)
Factor 2 score = 0.2 + 2.4 + 1.5 + 0.1 + 2.8 + 0.8 + 3 + 0.2 + 1.5 + 1.5
Factor 2 score = 14

Factor 3 score = (2 * 0.3) + (3 * 0.2) + (5 * 0.9) + (1 * 0.2) + (4 * 0.5) + (2 * 0.6) + (5 * 0.1) + (1 * 0.1) + (5 * 0.1) + (3 * 0.7)
Factor 3 score = 0.6 + 0.6 + 4.5 + 0.2 + 2 + 1.2 + 0.5 + 0.1 + 0.5 + 2.1
Factor 3 score = 12.3

So, the factor scores for the new observation are:
Factor 1: 12.6
Factor 2: 14
Factor 3: 12.3
